text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Centre Party takes victory in Sunday's municipal and European Parliament elections. Conservatives advance, Greens lose, "Young Finns" go nowhere.
- Biggest explanatory factor for changes in elections seems to be low voter turnout (around 60 percent), which the Centre Party avoided better than the others -- editorial column.
- Europoll victory especially sweet for Centre Party as it had feared its voters' might have grown passive because of Finland's EU membership -- editorial.
- Topping list of election winners is (Centre Party's) Paavo Vayrynen, who got what he wanted: "a basis for a return to the front ranks of Finnish politics" -- editorial.
- Almost half Finnish young people view tax evasion in a postive light, while 20 percent of the population admit to paying for illegal services, statistics show.
- Traditional divide between women's and men's jobs still strong. While some women have crossed over to male-dominated sectors, there has been little movement in the other direction.
KAUPPALEHTI
- Short-term interest-bearing funds have quickly absorbed almost all loose money on the market. During past 12 months, almost 2.7 billion markka has accumulated in these funds.
- Foods and feed group Raision Tehtaat has no big expectations for major earnings improvement in 1997 -- says its cholesterol-reducing Benecol margarine is long-term investment.
- Finnish listed companies more tight-lipped about their financing risks than their Swedish counterparts.
DEMARI
- Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen says linking markka to ERM did not have a negative impact on his Social Democratic Party's performance in the EU elections.
- Officials would like to make Finland a leading European country in fishing tourism.
AAMULEHTI
- Finns elected 16 representatives to Strasbourg-based Euro-parliament, returning only four incumbents in poll tinged with ERM protest. Most surprising winner: Centre's Samuli Pohjamo.
- Biggest election disappointment was the low turnout -- editorial.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Mainstream politicians fared better in Europarliament vote than the "celebrity" candidates.
--Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 235
